reviewText: Last night when I got home waiting for me was the DVD "All I Want." I intended to catch just a few minutes of it and instead spent the next several hours viewing it.The disc features a documentary made for British television which really is terrific. It consists mostly of interviews with Rufus, sister Martha, Mom Kate, Elton John, a couple of friends and various producers who've worked on the various Wainwright projects. Rufus and company are very open about his life, childhood, drug abuse, musical inspirations, relationship with his father, etc. It is, of course, punctuated with lots of music, mostly live performances.There are numerous bonus features, additional interviews not used in the final cut of the documentary, a handful of music videos, extensive concert footage from various shows, recording studio takes, etc. One particularly lovely song features Rufus in a concert in Montreal accompanied by the McGarrigle Sisters - mom, Kate at the piano (who wrote the song) and Aunt Anna singing harmony. It's really something special and sends the Montreal audience into a roar.A favorite live clip is of a flamboyantly costumed Rufus (as well as the entire band) performing "What a World" which of course opens with tubas and segues into it's main accompaniment, Ravel's Bolero with a boldness and an audicity that is guaranteed to bring a huge smile.For those of us who love opera AND Rufus - there is one wondrously hilarious video of the song "April Fools," which begins with Rufus waking up in bed (simultaneously) with Carmen, Tosca (a deadly serious Maria Callas clone), Gilda, Cio-Cio San (played by sister Martha), and Mimi who join him at the piano, scores in hand, and sing backup. Together they run through Hollywood each heroine eventually expiring according to her respective libretto. It is, like the boy himself, utterly charming.I can't recommend this enough - it's priced right, and is a great introduction to anyone wondering what all the fuss is about.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: John Frame "There Is No Substitute For Equality"
reviewText: "All I Want" is just about the best quality DVD I've seen - rich in content, artfully designed and authored, nothing less than superb in sight and sound.In the feature length documentary (covering up to and including "Want Two") we are privileged to witness Rufus Wainwright opening his heart and soul (as he already does through his music). He holds nothing back - sexuality, drugs, and paternal conflict are discussed as honestly as is his struggle for music industry acceptance. Anyone who already likes Rufus's voice and music will be greatly enriched by glimpsing such a broad view of what makes him tick.There is value in the included accolades from eminent musical celebrities Elton John and Sting. Elton especially could draw on his own life experience in guiding Rufus promptly to drug re-hab - which is the reason we still have Rufus with us.But I believe that it's his mother Kate,  sister Martha, close friends and long-term associates who clearly provide the ultimate relevance - after all they've seen him come through the trials an tribulations first-hand. "All I Want" is an incredibly moving, entertaining and ultimately rewarding biography.I've been blessed with the opportunity to interview Rufus by phone and to briefly meet with (and hug) him at a McGarrigle Family concert in Brisbane (Feb '05) - I know that with this DVD what you see is exactly what you get - honesty, humility and unrestrained talent.All of the many extras - including the music videos, live in the studio and concert performances and interviews combine to make this DVD great value - indispensable to anyone who might self-describe as a Rufus Wainwright fan.
summary: accurately  reflects the talent and honesty of Rufus himself
Title: N/A

reviewText: This rather awesome DVD is both a treat for fans of Rufus Wainwright, as well as people who may be getting into his music. As a fan, it only deepened my appreciation for his music and opened my eyes wider to his brilliance as a songwriter, singer, and performer and there's enough here to make someone only slightly familiar with the man want to dig further into his discography. With over three hours of various forms of material for you to enjoy, there's plenty here to soak up in increments or all at once. The material only covers his material through his stunningWant OneandWant Twoalbums, but having only released two albums since; it's still a stunning overview of his work. There are reviews aplenty here telling you what is contained on the DVD and various reviewers thoughts on that material, so I'll keep my descriptions and critiques as brief as possible.1. All I Want: A Portrait of Rufus WainwrightThis hour-long documentary covers Rufus' life from childhood through the recording of his four albums. Despite its rather short length, it covers this material pretty thoroughly. There are interviews with Rufus, his sister Martha, and his late mother Kate McGarrigle, as well as interviews with Elton John, Sting, Tom Chaplin (singer of Keane), and the band Scissor Sisters. While I enjoyed this documentary very much, I have but one trivial complaint; they didn't seem to find enough people to interview and as such we have the people they do interview reiterating their thoughts on Rufus' brilliance several times.2. The next section that features Rufus recording a new song called "The Maker Makes" and a short little video titled "Rufus Wainwright: 1998," that features some interviews and performance footage.3. The Studio Frisson Sessions are intimate performances with just Rufus and his piano or guitar performing Gay Messiah, Crumb by Crumb, Rebel Prince, The Art Teacher, This Love Affair, and Poses. They are lovely performances that show Rufus can is a top tier musician and singer in a studio or live setting.4. The Cambridge Corn Exchange Live features Rufus and his band performing four songs from Want One: Movies of Myself, Go or Go Ahead, I Don't Know What It Is, and Beautiful Child. Once again, these performances are stunning.5. Central Park Summerstage features Rufus performing Beauty Mark, Cigarettes and Chocolate Milk, and Dinner at Eight. This performance is probably the weakest of the performances, but they are still incredibly pleasing; especially his exceptional performance of Dinner at Eight.6. The music video section has his music videos for The One You Love, California, Cigarettes and Chocolate Milk, and April Fools. You can find them all on youtube, but they're a fun little addition.7. Finally, there is bonus interviews which feature Rufus, Martha, Kate McGarrigle, Rufus' Want sessions producer Marius de Vries, and the other musicians featured in the All I Want documentary discussing ten of Rufus' songs; the meaning behind them, the writing process, their various reactions to it, the recording process, etc. The songs discussed are I Don't Know What It Is, Gay Messiah, Poses, The Art Teacher, Go or Go Ahead, The One you Love, Beautiful Child, Rebel Prince, Movies of Myself, and Dinner at Eight. These bonus interviews are fascinating insights into the songs and only provided me with a deeper appreciation for them.Overall, this DVD is something I highly recommend you check out if you're interested in doing so. While any fan of Rufus may be craving more once it's all over, there's more here to satisfy than hardly any musician will provide you with on a DVD release.GRADE: A
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd have loved to hear Wainwright talk more about more of his songs and seen more performances.  It's a lovely introduction to an infectious, engaging, very talented--nay, brilliant--songwriter/poet/musician/performer.  The DVD covers a nice range of performance types -- concert settings with full band, intimate acoustic numbers (on a private stage or in studio), typical music video.  The interviews with Wainwright, friends, family, fellow artists & producers are interesting, leave you wanting to hear more.  Mostly I wanted to rush out and experience one of his concerts for myself.
summary: "All I Want" wasn't all I wanted, once I'd watched it.

reviewerName: Waldo McSheepington "and his bowl of turds"
reviewText: If you are interested in, a fan of, or simply amused by the gorgeous Mr. Wainwright, please check this DVD out. There are lots of live performances, all his music videos, and an extensive interview/documentary about his life and career so far.And there are 2 "Easter Eggs" included here - good ones, too. A shorter documentary with interviews from Rufus and his parents from 1998 which is a must see, and a quite hilarious comedic tribute by Rufus and his sister Martha to their mother and aunt of the McGarrigle sisters. (this easter egg needs to be viewed on a computer... just click over to the right side of the screen)
